sentences.sentence: By Dr. Zain ChaglaVaccinations are undoubtedly one of the most important public health interventions of the past two centuries.
The advent and distribution of vaccines to every corner of the Earth has allowed for us to mitigate some of our most potent pathogens, such as smallpox and measles.
Prior to COVID-19, we made the decision to get vaccinated, and accepted protection against the pathogen of concern without any question for brands or mechanisms.

As an infectious diseases physician under the age of 65, I cannot recall what brand of influenza vaccine I have received over the past five years.Fast forward through COVID-19, and the development of highly effective vaccines.
The incredible public nature of these vaccines has led to intense scrutiny of their use, safety profiles, rare side effects, efficacy, stability and other characteristics.
Individuals are digesting vaccinations and comparing brands as if shopping for a used car.

While this behaviour is encouraged to increase confidence in the vaccine, the reality is that all the approved vaccinations in Canada reduce hospitalization, death and disability from COVID-19, and protect against symptomatic disease, including to the variants of concern.MRNA vaccines work by tricking our bodies into making the spike protein, and then tricking our immune system into responding as if we've been infected with COVID-19.
The only difference between these vaccines and protein-based vaccines (i.e.
hepatitis B vaccine), is that our body makes the protein rather than the protein being injected.

The fundamental immune response is relatively similar across most vaccines, our effector cells learn how to deal with COVID-19, and a booster shot essentially reinforces that response.Confused about vaccine safety and efficacy?

An infectious disease expert answers some common questions(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/confused-about-vaccine-safety-and-efficacy-an-infectious-disease-expert-answers-some-common-questions)Jesse Kline: No, Tucker Carlson, vaccines aren't killing people by the thousands(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/jesse-kline-no-tucker-carlson-vaccines-arent-killing-people-by-the-thousands)So when we talk about mixing vaccines, it should not be surprising that this would be an effective strategy.
For Pfizer and Moderna, there are minor changes to the mRNA construct and the lipid particle, these differences amount to the difference between Coca-Cola and Pepsi.
Their effects on the immune system are identical for all intents and purposes.
Unfortunately due to brand recognition, a larger perception of differences has been created in terms of Moderna and Pfizer than what biologically exists.
If either vaccine is readily available, the advice is to finish the series with the dose you had.
However, the advice remains to take the first shot possible and protect yourself from getting sick from COVID-19, and your community from transmitting COVID-19.

Preferential vaccination will create bottlenecks of individuals demanding a particular vaccine, impairing the ability to get people vaccinated as quickly as possible to return to normal.While everyone worries about the brands, the advice still remains: take the first mRNA vaccine you can access.
Accessing your vaccine on time will get us back to normal faster, and put us back to pre-pandemic times, where your vaccine brand was unimportant.Dr.
Zain Chagla is an infectious diseases physician and an associate professor at McMaster University.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
